full_text:
Ever felt overwhelmed in the stock market? 

Imagine it like a supermarket, with aisles of different stocks. Peter Lynch, a famous investor, sorted them into 6 categories

Let's walk through this investment market & learn Peter Lynch's easy ways to understand stocks

A thread… https://t.co/KLOqfDO1MW
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: Peter Lynch, famed for his 29.2% average annual return at Fidelity Investments, stressed the importance of categorizing stocks in his book "One Up on Wall Street." \n\nUnderstanding a stock's unique traits is key for long-term returns, even 32 years later.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
Here is how Lynch has classified each stock into six broad categories:

1. The Slow Grower
Slow Growers are big, older companies that barely grow faster than the economy's average. 

They used to be fast-growing but now have a big market share in their slow-growing industry.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: They pay good dividends but don't see much growth in sales or earnings. \n\nPeter Lynch says the main reason to buy these stocks is for the dividends since they don't reinvest much for growth.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA
Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: Lynch suggests rotating among the companies, selling when moderate gains are reached, and repeating the process with others that haven’t yet appreciated. \n\nThese firms also offer downside protection during downturns.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
3. Fast Grower

These are usually small and aggressive companies (though not always) that grow at least 20% each year. 

Companies like KPIT Technologies fall under this "small and aggressive" category. However, remember even companies like Titan, can still be counted as a fast
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: grower in spite of being around for a long time. This is the place where you can expect multi-baggers but it does carry more risk than some of other categories mentioned above. \n\nThe risk comes from the market's expectations of growth and any slight disappointment would plummet
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: the stock. The obvious sell signal is the growth slowing down. It sounds easy to say but is actually difficult to spot. \n\nSome signals can be the entry of strong competitors and the earnings growth falling to the level of the market average.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
4. Turnaround

These are companies that were once well respected high flyers that now have their wings clipped. Lynch uses Chrysler as an example in his book. 

In today's terms it could be Orchid Pharma. If you own these stocks you have to realize that you are making a risky
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: bet and that it could totally burn out. So you can expect either high rewards or losing almost your entire capital. \n\nThis is the toughest category to spot a sell-signal, if the depressed PEs return to their pre-fall level, that is your sell signal.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
5. Cyclicals

Cyclical companies, like Materials & Mining firms, are heavily impacted by broader economic trends. 

They do well in economic upswings but struggle in downturns. 

These stocks are volatile, so owning them isn't easy unless you time the economic cycle correctly.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
For example, holding Steel stocks during a slowdown in China's economy isn't advisable. 

Lynch advises selling when you see inventory piling up. 

You cannot own, say NMDC, and expect to have a smooth ride up (unless you picked it right at the turn of the cycle).
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
6. Asset Plays

These are companies that own some asset that is valued higher than the total market cap of the company. 

Essentially you can buy the entire company, strip its assets into piecemeals, sell them and earn more than what you paid to buy the company.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text:
An Example of an Asset Play in Indian context was Bombay Dyeing. 

Bombay Dyeing as a company is a gruesome cash losing business. 

The company however owns a residential project with 270 units yet to be sold.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA

full_text: The total estimated value of this inventory is about 2100 crores, which was at that time slightly above its current market cap. \n\nThe basic sell signal in case of Asset play is when the company is valued at least equal to its net asset value.
name: Vivek Mashrani, CFA
